reviewText: If you like "Payback", which I did, you will enjoy "Get the Gringo".  In the making of the movie extras, Mel states there was nothing in the movie that they did not see in Mexico.  If that is true, then this film is somewhat of a revelation.  I think it was worth the cash, and Mel does very well in these sort of roles.  I don't know about the hand grenade bit in the film though. That was a lucky catch, and stretching reality; when you watch the film you will see what I mean.  I have thrown grenades and fired grenade launchers, and I for one, would get down in cover, rather than trying something heroic.  And unlike the movies, when a grenade goes off it is like thunder, shakes the ground, and is quite scary.

reviewText: Mel Gibson is back after several years from film in his usual edgy, "to the point" action rogue archetype character (how's that for too many details?). Tale opens with Gibson and his pals being pursued by Mexican police and not quite making it to the border. Gibson gets sent off to a prison which turns out to be prisoners with their families with a bunch of shanty towns formed around the crime boss of crime bosses. Along the way he picks up a meager number of allies, including a boisterous boy who is special in that he has the only matching liver and blood type for said crime boss.Gibson wrote this very engaging script. The movie went straight to DVD but it's hard to state that's because of Gibson's public image since he has been in a few big budget movies as of late.Public reviews for this action thriller have been high and DVD sales have been over $7M so far (it came out in May 2012).CINEMATOGRAPHY: B plus; BAIT AND SWITCH FOCUSES: B plus to A minus; CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE: B plus; STORY/PLOTTING/EDITING: B plus to A minus; WHEN WATCHED: early October 2012 (streamed); OVERALL GRADE: B plus to A minus.
summary: MY GRADE: B plus to A minus.

reviewText: This is a fantastic small film.  It's too bad Mel has the reputation he has.  If it wasn't for his very public fall, this film would have had awards.  It's a solid action movie and he can still be a leading man.  The writing and the action all come together to make this one of Mel's better efforts.  I'd watch it again for the strong performances and characters.
summary: Great Movie! One of Mel's best films ever!

reviewText: Loved the movie myself. It was sort of like they took Gibsons "porter" from the movie Payback & threw him in this crazy Mexican Prison.No spoilers other then the above & boy im real curious now if 'prisons' like the one portrayed here actualy exist, not that i'd want to find out firsthand ;>)Great Movie in my opinion.LOVED the 1st payback, hated the 2nd 'so called original' one released not long ago. Loved Get the Gringo & hope they dont ruin it in 10 years by doing what they did with payback & release another version that turns a 5 star movie in to a 1 or 2 star movie.But, do yourself a favor, watch Get The Gringo & see if YOU liked it. I sure did!
summary: Payback in a Crazy Mexican Prison

reviewText: Two clowns running from the law next to the U.S.-Mexico border get shot and crash the border.  Since the car is loaded with $ the Mexicans decide to take care of the driver and send him to... a communal prison/worst mall in the world.The driver figures out what he needs to know for $ and a gun.  Encounters a boy who says he is 'special' and his mom.Driver gets visited by U.S. official, driver doesn't divulge any useful info.Two officers that sent driver to prison show up, they have been spending $ and two of their friends are dead, they want to know where the $ came from. Then the owner of the $ finds them.Driver is let go to go get rid of somebody, funny to watch Mel do Clint Eastwood voice, perhaps this is an omage toEscape From Alcatraz.He does what he is supposed to and returns where he interrupts an organ transplant, just in time.Engaging, alot in Spanish so read or just guess based on verbal inflections.

reviewText: remember when Fonzie jumped the shark while surfing and invented the phrase "jump the shark" meaning the moment a failing franchise FINALLY overleaps the BS quotient and never recovers?Here an aging, overweight heavy smoking Mel Gibson jumps the balconies and completely goes off the BS reality radar screen. Bye bye Mel.but even the young ironic no BS Mel could not have saved this horrible arrogant mess which does nothing but appeal to anglo arrogance and false sense of superiority.This movie production is top heavy with anglos in fact, the entire writing, producing and directing team, with no MExicans at all to go, hey, wait a minute guys, this is way off the BS screen . . .It starts off promisingly enough, but then Mel jumps the international fence . . .near Tijuana and San Diego, with two million in cash . . .in an older Detroit sedanMad Max this ain'tnor is itMidnight Expressalthough filled with the greatest and latest of MExican actors, like SOsa from Alex COx's excellentHighway Patrolmanand the big guy you see in the MExican telenovelas, etc., and inSalvando Al Soldado Perezit seems no one dared get through to Mel about the story line, the acting, the performance, the reality.Instead we get the tired old gringo as god deal we have seen over and over again.and old Mel gets the girl . . .From the start the way mel walks into jail and takes charge is a joke, a bad joke, a very tired joke and remains so all the way through, the same way he jerks around all of the big time criminals and cops.This film plays to all that is most ugly in the anglo stereotypes of Mexico, and of prison and remains at that offensive yet popular level, and must have been a big hit for that reason alone. But we who know see it for the travesty and the huge waste that it is.He should have let a few actual Mexicans on to his writing team, and NOT ended with that highly offensive homophobic song.all in all eminently missable, appealing only to the already bigoted racist.
summary: anyone who loves THE GRINGO IS GOD kinda of fiction will love this; the rest of us should leave it alone

reviewText: In his personal life, Mel Gibson appears to be a complete mess and perhaps even mentally ill.  On screen, however, the man can still flat-out make a movie.  "Get the Gringo" wasn't released in U.S. theaters - althought it got a theatrical release everywhere else - reflecting his public perception slide here at home, but if you're a fan of his onscreen work, be sure to check this out.  It's a gritty modern noire with enough of the traditional Gibson levity to keep it from getting too dark - think "Payback" south of the border - and a great way to blow an hour and a half.
